steps.prompt: Learn about Active Directory Logical Structure: Forests, Trees, Domains, and OUs and understand: Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) is a distributed database storing network resources and app.
steps.title: Active Directory Logical Structure: Forests, Trees, Domains, and OUs
actions:
Read: Understanding the Active Directory Logical Model - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/identity/ad-ds/plan/understanding-the-active-directory-logical-model (5 min)
   Key concepts to note:
   • Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) is a distributed database storing network resources and app-specific data
   • Logical model organizes network elements into forest > domains > OUs, independent of physical topology
   • A forest is one or more domains sharing schema, configuration, and a global catalog
Practice: Follow along with a basic Active Directory Logical Structure: Forests, Trees, Domains, and OUs configuration example (15 min)
Self-test: Without looking at notes, explain Active Directory Logical Structure: Forests, Trees, Domains, and OUs to an imaginary coworker in 2-3 sentences (5 min)

steps.prompt: Learn the fundamentals of Active Directory Objects, Attributes, and Naming Standards and practice with a small exercise.
steps.title: Active Directory Objects, Attributes, and Naming Standards
actions: Read/skim: Naming conventions in Active Directory for computers, domains, sites, and OUs (20 min)
If you have AD access: run `gpresult /r` to see applied GPOs. If not: diagram what a GPO inheritance chain looks like (15 min)
Self-test: Without looking at notes, explain Active Directory Objects, Attributes, and Naming Standards to an imaginary coworker in 2-3 sentences (5 min)

steps.prompt: Learn about Active Directory Domain Controllers and Replication Topology and understand: Concept: A connection object represents an inbound replication link from a source domain controller .
steps.title: Active Directory Domain Controllers and Replication Topology
actions:
Read: Active Directory Replication Concepts - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/identity/ad-ds/get-started/replication/active-directory-replication-concepts (11 min)
   Key concepts to note:
   • Concept: A connection object represents an inbound replication link from a source domain controller to a destination DC
   • Concept: The KCC runs on every DC and automatically generates and adjusts replication topology forest-wide
   • Concept: Intrasite replication uses a bidirectional ring with shortcut links; intersite uses layered spanning trees per partition
Practice: Try 2-3 of the commands mentioned in the Active Directory Domain Controllers and Replication Topology documentation (15 min)
Self-test: Without looking at notes, explain Active Directory Domain Controllers and Replication Topology to an imaginary coworker in 2-3 sentences (5 min)

steps.prompt: Learn about Active Directory Authentication and Kerberos within a Domain and understand: Kerberos is the primary authentication protocol in Windows Server for verifying user and host identi.
steps.title: Active Directory Authentication and Kerberos within a Domain
actions:
Read: Kerberos authentication in Windows Server - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/security/kerberos/kerberos-authentication-overview (5 min)
   Key concepts to note:
   • Kerberos is the primary authentication protocol in Windows Server for verifying user and host identity
   • Windows implements Kerberos v5 with Microsoft extensions for public-key auth, authorization data, and delegation
   • The Key Distribution Center (KDC) runs on domain controllers and uses Active Directory as its account database
Practice: Try 2-3 of the commands mentioned in the Active Directory Authentication and Kerberos within a Domain documentation (15 min)
Self-test: Without looking at notes, explain Active Directory Authentication and Kerberos within a Domain to an imaginary coworker in 2-3 sentences (5 min)

steps.prompt: Learn the fundamentals of Active Directory Group Policy Objects: Scope, Linking, and Processing Order and practice with a small exercise.
steps.title: Active Directory Group Policy Objects: Scope, Linking, and Processing Order
actions: Read/skim: Group Policy processing and precedence in Windows (20 min)
If you have AD access: run `gpresult /r` to see applied GPOs. If not: diagram what a GPO inheritance chain looks like (15 min)
Self-test: Without looking at notes, explain Active Directory Group Policy Objects: Scope, Linking, and Processing Order to an imaginary coworker in 2-3 sentences (5 min)

steps.prompt: Put your Active Directory knowledge together with a practical challenge.
steps.title: BOSS: Active Directory Synthesis
actions: Quick review: Skim your notes from previous Active Directory days. What are the key concepts?
Mini-scenario: Design a simple AD structure for a company with 3 departments. Show: OUs, one GPO per department, and delegation for helpdesk
Self-assessment: What clicked? What's still fuzzy? What would you like to explore more?

steps.prompt: Learn about Active Directory Logical Structure: Forests, Trees, and Domains and understand: A forest is a top-level container of one or more domains sharing schema, configuration, and a global.
steps.title: Active Directory Logical Structure: Forests, Trees, and Domains
actions:
Read: Understanding the Active Directory Logical Model - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/identity/ad-ds/plan/understanding-the-active-directory-logical-model (5 min)
   Key concepts to note:
   • A forest is a top-level container of one or more domains sharing schema, configuration, and a global catalog
   • Domains in the same forest are linked by automatic two-way, transitive trust relationships
   • A domain is a partition that stores user accounts, provides authentication, replication, and authorization data
Practice: Follow along with a basic Active Directory Logical Structure: Forests, Trees, and Domains configuration example (15 min)
Self-test: Without looking at notes, explain Active Directory Logical Structure: Forests, Trees, and Domains to an imaginary coworker in 2-3 sentences (5 min)

steps.prompt: Learn about Organizational Units and Delegation of Control in Active Directory and understand: OUs let you delegate administration of user and computer objects to specific people or groups.
steps.title: Organizational Units and Delegation of Control in Active Directory
actions:
Read: Delegating Administration by Using OU Objects - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/identity/ad-ds/plan/delegating-administration-by-using-ou-objects (5 min)
   Key concepts to note:
   • OUs let you delegate administration of user and computer objects to specific people or groups
   • Delegation: put admins in a group, place objects in an OU, then delegate OU tasks to that group
   • AD DS supports granular delegation: full control, create/delete/manage accounts, or only reset passwords
Practice: Follow along with a basic Organizational Units and Delegation of Control in Active Directory configuration example (15 min)
Self-test: Without looking at notes, explain Organizational Units and Delegation of Control in Active Directory to an imaginary coworker in 2-3 sentences (5 min)

steps.prompt: Learn about Active Directory Objects and Attributes: Users, Computers, and Groups and understand: cn is the group's Common-Name, its relative distinguished name, and must be unique among sibling obj.
steps.title: Active Directory Objects and Attributes: Users, Computers, and Groups
actions:
Read: Group Objects - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/ad/group-objects (6 min)
   Key concepts to note:
   • cn is the group's Common-Name, its relative distinguished name, and must be unique among sibling objects
   • member is a multi-valued attribute of DNs; items are linked references AD updates on move/rename
   • groupType is an integer bitmask indicating scope (domain local/global/universal) and security flag
Practice: Review a sample Active Directory Objects and Attributes: Users, Computers, and Groups policy and identify what it allows/denies (15 min)
Self-test: Without looking at notes, explain Active Directory Objects and Attributes: Users, Computers, and Groups to an imaginary coworker in 2-3 sentences (5 min)

steps.prompt: Learn about Active Directory Group Types and Scope Management and understand: Security groups collect user accounts, computer accounts, and other groups into manageable units.
steps.title: Active Directory Group Types and Scope Management
actions:
Read: Active Directory Security Groups - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/identity/ad-ds/manage/understand-security-groups (11 min)
   Key concepts to note:
   • Security groups collect user accounts, computer accounts, and other groups into manageable units
   • Active Directory group types: Security groups and Distribution groups
   • Security groups assign permissions and user rights to resources and users
Practice: Follow along with a basic Active Directory Group Types and Scope Management configuration example (15 min)
Self-test: Without looking at notes, explain Active Directory Group Types and Scope Management to an imaginary coworker in 2-3 sentences (5 min)

steps.prompt: Learn about Active Directory Authentication and Kerberos Ticketing and understand: Kerberos is an authentication protocol used to verify user or host identities in Windows domains.
steps.title: Active Directory Authentication and Kerberos Ticketing
actions:
Read: Kerberos authentication overview - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/security/kerberos/kerberos-authentication-overview (5 min)
   Key concepts to note:
   • Kerberos is an authentication protocol used to verify user or host identities in Windows domains
   • Windows implements Kerberos V5 plus extensions for public-key authentication, authz data transport, and delegation
   • The Kerberos client is a Security Support Provider (SSP) accessed through the Security Support Provider Interface (SSPI)
Practice: Try 2-3 of the commands mentioned in the Active Directory Authentication and Kerberos Ticketing documentation (15 min)
Self-test: Without looking at notes, explain Active Directory Authentication and Kerberos Ticketing to an imaginary coworker in 2-3 sentences (5 min)

steps.prompt: Put your Active Directory knowledge together with a practical challenge.
steps.title: BOSS: Active Directory Synthesis
actions: Quick review: Skim your notes from previous Active Directory days. What are the key concepts?
Mini-scenario: Design a simple AD structure for a company with 3 departments. Show: OUs, one GPO per department, and delegation for helpdesk
Self-assessment: What clicked? What's still fuzzy? What would you like to explore more?
